PAL.NAME: Microsoft Exchange 2013
PAL.DESCRIPTION: Analyzes Exchange 2013 data to aid troubleshooting and system health reporting. Thresholds are referenced at the following link: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn904093%28v=exchg.150%29.aspx

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange ADAccess Domain Controllers LDAP Read Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
LDAP Read Time for a given DC is the time (in milliseconds) taken to send an LDAP read request to the specified DC and receive a response.

  • Should be below 50 ms on average.
  • Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 100 ms.
Further Reading: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa998561%28v=exchg.150%29.aspx

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange ADAccess Domain Controllers LDAP Search Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
LDAP Search Time is the time (in milliseconds) taken to send an LDAP search request and receive a response.

  • Should be below 50 ms on average.
  • Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 100 ms.
Further Reading: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa998561%28v=exchg.150%29.aspx

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange ADAccess Processes LDAP Read Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
LDAP Read Time is the time (in milliseconds) taken to send an LDAP read request and receive a response.

  • Should be below 50 ms on average.
  • Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 100 ms.
Further Reading: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa998561%28v=exchg.150%29.aspx

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange ADAccess Processes LDAP Search Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
LDAP Search Time is the time (in milliseconds) taken to send an LDAP search request and receive a response.

  • Should be below 50 ms on average.
  • Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 100 ms.
Further Reading: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa998561%28v=exchg.150%29.aspx

ANALYSIS.NAME: Processor % Processor Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
% Processor Time is the percentage of elapsed time that the processor spends to execute a non-Idle thread. It is calculated by measuring the percentage of time that the processor spends executing the idle thread and then subtracting that value from 100%. (Each processor has an idle thread that consumes cycles when no other threads are ready to run). This counter is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed during the sample interval.

  • This value should be less than 75% on average.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Processor % User Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: % User Time is the percentage of elapsed time the processor spends in the user mode. User mode is a restricted processing mode designed for applications, environment subsystems, and integral subsystems. The alternative, privileged mode, is designed for operating system components and allows direct access to hardware and all memory. The operating system switches application threads to privileged mode to access operating system services. This counter displays the average busy time as a percentage of the sample time.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Processor % Privileged Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
% Privileged Time is the percentage of elapsed time that the process threads spent executing code in privileged mode. When a Windows system service in called, the service will often run in privileged mode to gain access to system-private data. Such data is protected from access by threads executing in user mode. Calls to the system can be explicit or implicit, such as page faults or interrupts. Unlike some early operating systems, Windows uses process boundaries for subsystem protection in addition to the traditional protection of user and privileged modes. Some work done by Windows on behalf of the application might appear in other subsystem processes in addition to the privileged time in the process.

  • This value should be less than 75% on average

ANALYSIS.NAME: System Processor Queue Length
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Processor Queue Length is the number of threads in the processor queue. Unlike the disk counters, this counter counters, this counter shows ready threads only, not threads that are running. There is a single queue for processor time even on computers with multiple processors. Therefore, if a computer has multiple processors, you need to divide this value by the number of processors servicing the workload.

  • A sustained processor queue of less than 10 threads per processor is normally acceptable, dependent of the workload

ANALYSIS.NAME: Memory Available MBytes
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Shows the amount of physical memory, in megabytes (MB), immediately available for allocation to a process or for system use. It's equal to the sum of memory assigned to the standby (cached), free, and zero page lists.

  • This value should remain above 5% of total RAM.
Further Reading: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/2160852/

ANALYSIS.NAME: Memory % Committed Bytes In Use
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
% Committed Bytes In Use is the ratio of Memory\\Committed Bytes to the Memory\\Commit Limit. Committed memory is the physical memory in use for which space has been reserved in the paging file should it need to be written to disk. The commit limit is determined by the size of the paging file. If the paging file is enlarged, the commit limit increases, and the ratio is reduced). This counter displays the current percentage value only; it is not an average.

  • If this value is more than 80%, it is an indication that the system is likely under stress to provide more memory.
Further Reading: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/2160852/

ANALYSIS.NAME: .NET CLR Memory % Time in GC
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows when garbage collection has occurred. When the counter exceeds the threshold, it indicates that CPU is cleaning up and isn't being used efficiently for load. Adding memory to the server would improve this situation. This value should be below 10% on average.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Network Interface Packets Outbound Errors
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Packets Outbound Errors is the number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors.

  • This value should be 0 at all times

ANALYSIS.NAME: TCPv4 Connections Reset
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Connections Reset is the number of times TCP connections have made a direct transition to the CLOSED state from either the ESTABLISHED state or the CLOSE-WAIT state.

  • An increasing number of resets or a consistently increasing rate of resets can indicate a bandwidth shortage.

ANALYSIS.NAME: TCPv6 Connections Reset
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Connections Reset is the number of times TCP connections have made a direct transition to the CLOSED state from either the ESTABLISHED state or the CLOSE-WAIT state.

  • An increasing number of resets or a consistently increasing rate of resets can indicate a bandwidth shortage.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Netlogon Semaphore Waiters
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Number of thread currently waiting to acquire the semaphore. See Microsoft Knowledge Base article 2688798:

  • How to do performance tuning for NTLM authentication by using the MaxConcurrentAPI setting

ANALYSIS.NAME: TCPv6 Connection Failures
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of TCP connections for which the current state is either ESTABLISHED or CLOSE-WAIT. The number of TCP connections that can be established is constrained by the size of the nonpaged pool. When the nonpaged pool is depleted, no new connections can be established.

ANALYSIS.NAME: .NET CLR Memory # Bytes in all Heaps
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \.NET CLR Memory(*)\# Bytes in all Heaps

DATASOURCE.NAME: \.NET CLR Memory(*)\# Bytes in all Heaps
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \.NET CLR Memory(*)\# Bytes in all Heaps

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \.NET CLR Memory(*)\# Bytes in all Heaps
CHART.DATASOURCE: \.NET CLR Memory(*)\# Bytes in all Heaps

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: This counter is the sum of four other counters; Gen 0 Heap Size; Gen 1 Heap Size; Gen 2 Heap Size and the Large Object Heap Size. This counter indicates the current memory allocated in bytes on the GC Heaps.

ANALYSIS.NAME: .NET CLR Exceptions # of Exceps Thrown / sec
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \.NET CLR Exceptions(*)\# of Exceps Thrown / sec

DATASOURCE.NAME: \.NET CLR Exceptions(*)\# of Exceps Thrown / sec
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \.NET CLR Exceptions(*)\# of Exceps Thrown / sec

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \.NET CLR Exceptions(*)\# of Exceps Thrown / sec
CHART.DATASOURCE: \.NET CLR Exceptions(*)\# of Exceps Thrown / sec

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Displays the number of exceptions thrown per second. These include both .NET Framework exceptions and unmanaged exceptions that get converted into .NET Framework exceptions. For example, the null pointer reference exception in unmanaged code would get thrown again in managed code as a .NET Framework System.NullReferenceException. This counter includes both handled and unhandled exceptions.

  • Should be less than 5% of total requests per second (RPS) (Web Server(_Total)\Connection Attempts/sec * .05).

ANALYSIS.NAME: Process % Processor Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: % Processor Time is the percentage of elapsed time that all of process threads used the processor to execution instructions. An instruction is the basic unit of execution in a computer, a thread is the object that executes instructions, and a process is the object created when a program is run. Code executed to handle some hardware interrupts and trap conditions are included in this count. This can be used to identify specific processes consuming CPU.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Netlogon Semaphore Holders
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Number of thread currently holding the semaphore.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Netlogon Semaphore Acquires
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The total number of times the semaphore has been acquired over the lifetime of the Secure Channel connection (or since system boot for _Total).

ANALYSIS.NAME: Netlogon Semaphore Timeouts
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The total number of times a thread has timed out waiting for the semaphore over the lifetime of the Secure Channel connection (or since system boot for _Total).

ANALYSIS.NAME: Netlogon Semaphore Timeouts
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The total number of times a thread has timed out waiting for the semaphore over the lifetime of the Secure Channel connection (or since system boot for _Total).

ANALYSIS.NAME: Netlogon Average Semaphore Hold Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average amount of time the semaphore is held over the last sample.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Database ==> Instances I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency

DATASOURCE.NAME: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency
CHART.DATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency is the average length of time, in milliseconds, per database read operation.

  • The value should be less than 20ms average

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Database ==> Instances I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency

DATASOURCE.NAME: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency
CHART.DATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency is the average length of time, in milliseconds, per database write operation.

  • Should be less than 50ms on average.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Database ==> Instances I/O Log Writes Average Latency
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Log Writes Average Latency

DATASOURCE.NAME: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Log Writes Average Latency
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Log Writes Average Latency

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Log Writes Average Latency
CHART.DATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Log Writes Average Latency

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
I/O Log Writes Average Latency is the average length of time, in milliseconds, per log file write operation.

  • The value should be less than 10ms average

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Database ==> Instances I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency

DATASOURCE.NAME: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency
CHART.DATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency is the average length of time, in milliseconds, per database read operation.

  • This value should be less than 200ms on average.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Database ==> Instances I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency

DATASOURCE.NAME: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency
CHART.DATASOURCE: \MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency is the average length of time, in milliseconds, per database write operation.

  • The value should be less than the read latency for the same instance, as measured by the MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency counter.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Database ==> Instances I/O Database Reads (Attached)/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of database read operations per second for each attached database instance

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Database ==> Instances I/O Database Writes (Attached)/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of database write operations per second for each attached database instance.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Database ==> Instances I/O Log Writes/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of log writes per second for each database instance.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Active Manager Database Mounted
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Shows the number of active database copies on the server.

  • Is the database mounted? Possible values are: 0 if it is not mounted, 1 if it is mounted.

ANALYSIS.NAME: ASP.NET Application Restarts
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Number of times the application has been restarted during the web server's lifetime.

ANALYSIS.NAME: ASP.NET Worker Process Restarts
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Number of times a worker process has restarted on the machine.

ANALYSIS.NAME: ASP.NET Request Wait Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of milliseconds the most recent request was waiting in the queue.

ANALYSIS.NAME: ASP.NET Applications Requests In Application Queue
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of requests in the application request queue.

ANALYSIS.NAME: ASP.NET Applications Requests Executing
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of requests currently executing.

ANALYSIS.NAME: ASP.NET Applications Requests/Sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of requests executed per second.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange RpcClientAccess RPC Averaged Latency
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
RPC Averaged Latency is the latency, in milliseconds, averaged for the past 1024 packets.

  • This value should be below than 250ms

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange RpcClientAccess RPC Requests
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
RPC Requests is the number of client requests that are currently being processed by the RPC Client Access service.

  • This value should not be over 40

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange RpcClientAccess Active User Count
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Active User Count is the number of unique users that have shown some activity in the last 2 minutes.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange RpcClientAccess Connection Count
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Connection Count is the total number of client connections maintained.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange RpcClientAccess RPC Operations/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: RPC Operations/sec is the rate at which RPC operations occur, per second.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange RpcClientAccess User Count
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: User Count is the number of users that are connected to the service.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange HttpProxy MailboxServerLocator Average Latency
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average latency (ms) of MailboxServerLocator web service calls.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange HttpProxy Average Authentication Latency
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average time spent authenticating CAS requests over the last 200 samples.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange HttpProxy Average ClientAccess Server Processing Latency
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average latency (ms) of CAS processing time (does not include time spent proxying) over the last 200 requests.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange HttpProxy Mailbox Server Proxy Failure Rate
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The percentage of connectivity related failures between this Client Access Server and MBX servers over the last 200 samples.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange HttpProxy Outstanding Proxy Requests
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of concurrent outstanding proxy requests.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange HttpProxy Proxy Requests/Sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of proxy requests processed each second.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange HttpProxy Requests/Sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of requests processed each second which may not involve proxying to a Mailbox server.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchangeIS Client Type RPC Requests
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: RPC Requests that are currently in progress.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchangeIS Client Type RPC Average Latency
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Shows a server RPC latency, in ms, averaged for the past 1,024 packets for a particular client protocol.

  • This value should be less than 50 ms on average for each client.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchangeIS Store RPC Average Latency
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
RPC Latency average (msec) is the average latency in milliseconds of RPC requests per database. Average is calculated over all RPCs since exrpc32 was loaded.

  • Should be less than 50ms at all times, with spikes less than 100ms

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchangeIS Store RPC Operations/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: RPC Operations/sec is the number of RPC operations that are processed each second per database

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchangeIS Client Type RPC Operations/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: RPC Operations/sec is the number of RPC operations that are processed each second.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange ActiveSync Requests/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of HTTP requests received from the client via ASP.NET per second. Determines the current Exchange ActiveSync request rate. Used only to determine current user load

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange ActiveSync Ping Commands Pending
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of ping commands currently pending in the queue.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange ActiveSync Sync Commands/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of sync commands processed per second. Clients use this command to synchronize items within a folder.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange Availability Service\Availability Requests Availability Requests (sec)
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of requests serviced per second. The request can be only for free/ busy information or include suggestions. One request may contain multiple mailboxes. Determines the rate at which Availability service requests are occurring.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange OWA Current Unique Users
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of unique users currently logged on to Outlook Web App. This value monitors the number of unique active user sessions, so that users are only removed from this counter after they log off or their session times out. Determines current user load.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange OWA Requests/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of requests handled by Outlook Web App per second. Determines current user load.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchangeAutodiscover Requests/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of Autodiscover service requests processed each second. Determines current user load.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchangeWS Requests/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of requests processed each second. Determines current user load.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Web Service Current Connections
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the current number of connections established with the Web service. Determines current user load.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Web Service Current Connections
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the current number of connections established to the Default website which corresponds to the number of connections hitting the Front End CAS server role. Determines current user load.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Web Service Connection Attempts/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the rate that connections to the Web service are being attempted. Determines current user load.

ANALYSIS.NAME: Web Service Other Request Methods/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the rate HTTP requests are made that don't use the OPTIONS, GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, TRACE, MOVE, COPY, MKCOL, PROPFIND, PROPPATCH, SEARCH, LOCK, or UNLOCK methods. Determines current user load.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange WorkloadManagement Workloads ActiveTasks
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of active tasks currently running in the background for workload management.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange WorkloadManagement Workloads CompletedTasks
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of workload management tasks that have been completed.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSExchange WorkloadManagement Workloads QueuedTasks
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the number of workload management tasks that are currently queued up waiting to be processed
